sections.pali: [pārā. 1 ādayo] Evaṃ me sutaṃ – ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā verañjāyaṃ viharati naḷerupucimandamūle. Atha kho verañjo brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ [sārāṇīyaṃ (sī. syā. kaṃ. pī.)] vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho verañjo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘Sutaṃ metaṃ, bho gotama – ‘na samaṇo gotamo brāhmaṇe jiṇṇe vuḍḍhe mahallake addhagate vayoanuppatte abhivādeti vā paccuṭṭheti vā āsanena vā nimantetī’ti. Tayidaṃ, bho gotama, tatheva. Na hi bhavaṃ gotamo brāhmaṇe jiṇṇe vuḍḍhe mahallake addhagate vayoanuppatte abhivādeti vā paccuṭṭheti vā āsanena vā nimanteti. Tayidaṃ, bho gotama, na sampannamevā’’ti. ‘‘Nāhaṃ taṃ, brāhmaṇa, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya yamahaṃ abhivādeyyaṃ vā paccuṭṭheyyaṃ vā āsanena vā nimanteyyaṃ. Yañhi, brāhmaṇa, tathāgato abhivādeyya vā paccuṭṭheyya vā āsanena vā nimanteyya, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyā’’ti. ‘‘Arasarūpo bhavaṃ gotamo’’ti! ‘‘Atthi khvesa, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘arasarūpo samaṇo gotamo’ti. Ye te, brāhmaṇa, rūparasā saddarasā gandharasā rasarasā phoṭṭhabbarasā, te tathāgatassa pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṃkatā [anabhāvakatā (sī. pī.)] āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā. Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘arasarūpo samaṇo gotamo’ti, no ca kho yaṃ tvaṃ sandhāya vadesī’’ti [vadesi (sī. ka.)]. ‘‘Nibbhogo bhavaṃ gotamo’’ti! ‘‘Atthi khvesa, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘nibbhogo samaṇo gotamo’ti. Ye te, brāhmaṇa, rūpabhogā saddabhogā gandhabhogā rasabhogā phoṭṭhabbabhogā, te tathāgatassa pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṃkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā. Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘nibbhogo samaṇo gotamo’ti, no ca kho yaṃ tvaṃ sandhāya vadesī’’ti. ‘‘Akiriyavādo bhavaṃ gotamo’’ti! ‘‘Atthi khvesa, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘akiriyavādo samaṇo gotamo’ti. Ahañhi, brāhmaṇa, akiriyaṃ vadāmi kāyaduccaritassa vacīduccaritassa manoduccaritassa; anekavihitānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ akiriyaṃ vadāmi. Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘akiriyavādo samaṇo gotamo’ti, no ca kho yaṃ tvaṃ sandhāya vadesī’’ti. ‘‘Ucchedavādo bhavaṃ gotamo’’ti! ‘‘Atthi khvesa, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘ucchedavādo samaṇo gotamo’ti. Ahañhi, brāhmaṇa, ucchedaṃ vadāmi rāgassa dosassa mohassa; anekavihitānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ucchedaṃ vadāmi. Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘ucchedavādo samaṇo gotamo’ti, no ca kho yaṃ tvaṃ sandhāya vadesī’’ti. ‘‘Jegucchī bhavaṃ gotamo’’ti! ‘‘Atthi khvesa, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘jegucchī samaṇo gotamo’ti. Ahañhi, brāhmaṇa, jigucchāmi kāyaduccaritena vacīduccaritena manoduccaritena; jigucchāmi anekavihitānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ samāpattiyā. Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘jegucchī samaṇo gotamo’ti, no ca kho yaṃ tvaṃ sandhāya vadesī’’ti. ‘‘Venayiko bhavaṃ gotamo’’ti! ‘‘Atthi khvesa, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘venayiko samaṇo gotamo’ti. Ahañhi, brāhmaṇa, vinayāya dhammaṃ desemi rāgassa dosassa mohassa; anekavihitānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ vinayāya dhammaṃ desemi. Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘venayiko samaṇo gotamo’ti, no ca kho yaṃ tvaṃ sandhāya vadesī’’ti. ‘‘Tapassī bhavaṃ gotamo’’ti! ‘‘Atthi khvesa, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘tapassī samaṇo gotamo’ti. Tapanīyāhaṃ, brāhmaṇa, pāpake akusale dhamme vadāmi kāyaduccaritaṃ vacīduccaritaṃ manoduccaritaṃ. Yassa kho, brāhmaṇa, tapanīyā pāpakā akusalā dhammā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṃkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā, tamahaṃ ‘tapassī’ti vadāmi. Tathāgatassa kho, brāhmaṇa, tapanīyā pāpakā akusalā dhammā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṃkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā. Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘tapassī samaṇo gotamo’ti, no ca kho yaṃ tvaṃ sandhāya vadesī’’ti. ‘‘Apagabbho bhavaṃ gotamo’’ti! ‘‘Atthi khvesa, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘apagabbho samaṇo gotamo’ti. Yassa kho, brāhmaṇa, āyatiṃ gabbhaseyyā punabbhavābhinibbatti pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṃkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā, tamahaṃ ‘apagabbho’ti vadāmi. Tathāgatassa kho, brāhmaṇa, āyatiṃ gabbhaseyyā punabbhavābhinibbatti pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṃkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā. Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘apagabbho samaṇo gotamo’ti, no ca kho yaṃ tvaṃ sandhāya vadesi. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, brāhmaṇa, kukkuṭiyā aṇḍāni aṭṭha vā dasa vā dvādasa vā. Tānāssu kukkuṭiyā sammā adhisayitāni sammā pariseditāni sammā paribhāvitāni. Yo nu kho tesaṃ kukkuṭacchāpakānaṃ paṭhamataraṃ pādanakhasikhāya vā mukhatuṇḍakena vā aṇḍakosaṃ padāletvā sotthinā abhinibbhijjeyya, kinti svāssa vacanīyo – ‘jeṭṭho vā kaniṭṭho vā’’’ti? ‘‘Jeṭṭho tissa, bho gotama, vacanīyo. So hi nesaṃ, bho gotama, jeṭṭho hotī’’ti. ‘‘Evamevaṃ kho ahaṃ, brāhmaṇa, avijjāgatāya pajāya aṇḍabhūtāya pariyonaddhāya avijjaṇḍakosaṃ padāletvā ekova loke anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho. Ahañhi, brāhmaṇa, jeṭṭho seṭṭho lokassa. Āraddhaṃ kho pana me, brāhmaṇa, vīriyaṃ ahosi asallīnaṃ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṃ cittaṃ ekaggaṃ. ‘‘So kho ahaṃ, brāhmaṇa, vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi; vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi; pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharāmi sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedemi yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti – ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi; sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi. ‘‘So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmesiṃ. So anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi, seyyathidaṃ – ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe – ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto. So tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto. So tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi. ‘‘Ayaṃ kho me, brāhmaṇa, rattiyā paṭhame yāme paṭhamā vijjā adhigatā; avijjā vihatā vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato āloko uppanno, yathā taṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato. Ayaṃ kho me, brāhmaṇa, paṭhamā abhinibbhidā ahosi kukkuṭacchāpakasseva aṇḍakosamhā. ‘‘So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṃ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmesiṃ. So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passāmi cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāmi – ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā, vacīduccaritena samannāgatā, manoduccaritena samannāgatā, ariyānaṃ upavādakā, micchādiṭṭhikā, micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannāti. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā, vacīsucaritena samannāgatā, manosucaritena samannāgatā, ariyānaṃ anupavādakā, sammādiṭṭhikā, sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passāmi cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāmi. ‘‘Ayaṃ kho me, brāhmaṇa, rattiyā majjhime yāme dutiyā vijjā adhigatā; avijjā vihatā vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato āloko uppanno, yathā taṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato. Ayaṃ kho me, brāhmaṇa, dutiyā abhinibbhidā ahosi kukkuṭacchāpakasseva aṇḍakosamhā. ‘‘So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṃ khayañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmesiṃ. So ‘idaṃ dukkha’nti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ; ‘ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ. Tassa me evaṃ jānato evaṃ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccittha, bhavāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccittha, avijjāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccittha. Vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ ahosi. ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti abbhaññāsiṃ. ‘‘Ayaṃ kho me, brāhmaṇa, rattiyā pacchime yāme tatiyā vijjā adhigatā; avijjā vihatā vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato āloko uppanno, yathā taṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato. Ayaṃ kho me, brāhmaṇa, tatiyā abhinibbhidā ahosi kukkuṭacchāpakasseva aṇḍakosamhā’’ti. Evaṃ vutte verañjo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘jeṭṭho bhavaṃ gotamo, seṭṭho bhavaṃ gotamo. Abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama, abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama! Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ [nikujjitaṃ (ka.)] vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya – cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantīti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito. Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca. Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gata’’nti. Paṭhamaṃ.
sections.english:
Thus have I heard. On one occasion the Blessed One was staying in Verañjā, at the root of a Naḷeru-pucimanda tree.

Then the brahmin Verañja approached the Blessed One. Having approached, he exchanged greetings with the Blessed One. After exchanging cordial greetings, he sat down to one side.

Seated to one side, the brahmin Verañja said to the Blessed One: ‘I have heard this, Master Gotama: “The recluse Gotama does not greet brahmins who are old, aged, advanced in years, having come to the last stage of life, nor does he rise up for them, nor does he invite them to a seat.” This, Master Gotama, is indeed true. For Master Gotama does not greet brahmins who are old, aged, advanced in years, having come to the last stage of life, nor does he rise up for them, nor does he invite them to a seat. This, Master Gotama, is not proper.’

‘Brahmin, I do not see anyone in the world with its deities, Māras, and Brahmās, in this generation with its recluses and brahmins, its gods and humans, whom I should greet, rise up for, or invite to a seat. For if the Tathāgata were to greet, rise up for, or invite someone to a seat, that one’s head would surely split apart.’

‘Master Gotama is without taste!’

‘Brahmin, there is indeed a way in which one, speaking rightly, might say of me: “The recluse Gotama is without taste.” Those tastes of forms, tastes of sounds, tastes of odors, tastes of flavors, tastes of tactile objects – these have been abandoned by the Tathāgata, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, brought to non-existence, and are incapable of future arising. This, brahmin, is the way in which one, speaking rightly, might say of me: “The recluse Gotama is without taste,” but not in the sense that you mean.’

‘Master Gotama is devoid of enjoyments!’

‘Brahmin, there is indeed a way in which one, speaking rightly, might say of me: “The recluse Gotama is devoid of enjoyments.” Those enjoyments of forms, enjoyments of sounds, enjoyments of odors, enjoyments of flavors, enjoyments of tactile objects – these have been abandoned by the Tathāgata, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, brought to non-existence, and are incapable of future arising. This, brahmin, is the way in which one, speaking rightly, might say of me: “The recluse Gotama is devoid of enjoyments,” but not in the sense that you mean.’

‘Master Gotama is an advocate of non-action!’

‘Brahmin, there is indeed a way in which one, speaking rightly, might say of me: “The recluse Gotama is an advocate of non-action.” For, brahmin, I advocate non-action regarding misconduct by body, misconduct by speech, and misconduct by mind. I advocate non-action regarding various kinds of evil and unwholesome states. This, brahmin, is the way in which one, speaking rightly, might say of me: “The recluse Gotama is an advocate of non-action,” but not in the sense that you mean.’

‘Master Gotama is an annihilationist!’

‘Brahmin, there is indeed a way in which one, speaking rightly, might say of me: “The recluse Gotama is an annihilationist.” For, brahmin, I advocate the annihilation of lust, hatred, and delusion. I advocate the annihilation of various kinds of evil and unwholesome states. This, brahmin, is the way in which one, speaking rightly, might say of me: “The recluse Gotama is an annihilationist,” but not in the sense that you mean.’

‘Master Gotama is an abhorrer!’

‘Brahmin, there is indeed a way in which one, speaking rightly, might say of me: “The recluse Gotama is an abhorrer.” For, brahmin, I abhor misconduct by body, misconduct by speech, and misconduct by mind. I abhor the entering into various kinds of evil and unwholesome states. This, brahmin, is the way in which one, speaking rightly, might say of me: “The recluse Gotama is an abhorrer,” but not in the sense that you mean.’

‘Master Gotama is a disciplinarian!’

‘Brahmin, there is indeed a way in which one, speaking rightly, might say of me: “The recluse Gotama is a disciplinarian.” For, brahmin, I teach the Dhamma for the removal of lust, hatred, and delusion. I teach the Dhamma for the removal of various kinds of evil and unwholesome states. This, brahmin, is the way in which one, speaking rightly, might say of me: “The recluse Gotama is a disciplinarian,” but not in the sense that you mean.’

‘Master Gotama is an ascetic!’

‘Brahmin, there is indeed a way in which one, speaking rightly, might say of me: “The recluse Gotama is an ascetic.” For, brahmin, I declare evil and unwholesome states to be scorching; namely, misconduct by body, misconduct by speech, and misconduct by mind. If, brahmin, those scorching evil and unwholesome states have been abandoned, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, brought to non-existence, and are incapable of future arising, then I call that person an ascetic. For the Tathāgata, brahmin, those scorching evil and unwholesome states have been abandoned, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, brought to non-existence, and are incapable of future arising. This, brahmin, is the way in which one, speaking rightly, might say of me: “The recluse Gotama is an ascetic,” but not in the sense that you mean.’

‘Master Gotama is one who is free from rebirth in a womb!’

‘Brahmin, there is indeed a way in which one, speaking rightly, might say of me: “The recluse Gotama is one who is free from rebirth in a womb.” If, brahmin, future rebirth in a womb and the renewed existence that implies have been abandoned, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, brought to non-existence, and are incapable of future arising, then I call that person one who is free from rebirth in a womb. For the Tathāgata, brahmin, future rebirth in a womb and the renewed existence that implies have been abandoned, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, brought to non-existence, and are incapable of future arising. This, brahmin, is the way in which one, speaking rightly, might say of me: “The recluse Gotama is one who is free from rebirth in a womb,” but not in the sense that you mean.

‘Just as, brahmin, there might be eight, ten, or twelve hen’s eggs. These eggs would be well brooded over, well incubated, well nurtured by the hen. Then, whichever of those chicks first breaks through the eggshell with the tip of its claw or with its beak and emerges safely, what would that one be called – the eldest or the youngest?’

‘It would be called the eldest, Master Gotama. For that one, Master Gotama, would be the eldest.’

‘Even so, brahmin, I alone, having broken through the eggshell of ignorance, which enveloped this generation steeped in ignorance and egg-bound, have attained unsurpassed perfect self-awakening in the world. I am, brahmin, the eldest and the foremost in the world. Furthermore, brahmin, my energy was aroused and unflagging, my mindfulness was established and unconfused, my body was tranquil and unagitated, my mind was concentrated and one-pointed.

‘Then, brahmin, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, I entered upon and abided in the first jhāna, which is accompanied by initial application and sustained application, born of seclusion, and filled with rapture and happiness. With the stilling of initial and sustained application, I entered upon and abided in the second jhāna, which has internal assurance and unification of mind, is without initial application and sustained application, born of concentration, and filled with rapture and happiness. With the fading away of rapture, I abided in equanimity, mindful and clearly comprehending, and I experienced happiness with the body, of which the noble ones declare: “He abides in happiness with equanimity and mindfulness.” Thus, I entered upon and abided in the third jhāna. With the abandoning of pleasure and pain, and with the prior disappearance of joy and grief, I entered upon and abided in the fourth jhāna, which is neither painful nor pleasant, and is purified by equanimity and mindfulness.

‘With the mind thus concentrated, purified, cleansed, unblemished, rid of defilement, pliant, workable, steady, and attained to imperturbability, I directed it to the knowledge of recollecting past lives. I recollected my manifold past lives, that is, one birth, two births, three births, four births, five births, ten births, twenty births, thirty births, forty births, fifty births, a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births, many eons of cosmic contraction, many eons of cosmic expansion, many eons of cosmic contraction and expansion. “There I was of such a name, such a clan, such a complexion, such a diet, I experienced such pleasure and pain, and my life span was such. Having passed away from there, I reappeared elsewhere. There too I was of such a name, such a clan, such a complexion, such a diet, I experienced such pleasure and pain, and my life span was such. Having passed away from there, I reappeared here.” Thus, with their aspects and particulars, I recollected my manifold past lives.

‘This, brahmin, was the first knowledge attained by me in the first watch of the night; ignorance was dispelled, knowledge arose; darkness was dispelled, light arose, as is fitting for one who abides diligent, ardent, and resolute. This, brahmin, was my first breakthrough, like that of the chick from its eggshell.

‘With the mind thus concentrated, purified, cleansed, unblemished, rid of defilement, pliant, workable, steady, and attained to imperturbability, I directed it to the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings. With the divine eye, purified and surpassing that of humans, I saw beings passing away and reappearing, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate, and I understood how beings fare according to their actions. “These beings, alas, engaged in misconduct by body, speech, and mind, revilers of noble ones, holding wrong views, and undertaking actions based on wrong views, with the breakup of the body, after death, have reappeared in a state of deprivation, a bad destination, a lower realm, hell. But these beings, alas, engaged in good conduct by body, speech, and mind, not revilers of noble ones, holding right views, and undertaking actions based on right views, with the breakup of the body, after death, have reappeared in a good destination, a heavenly world.” Thus, with the divine eye, purified and surpassing that of humans, I saw beings passing away and reappearing, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate, and I understood how beings fare according to their actions.

‘This, brahmin, was the second knowledge attained by me in the middle watch of the night; ignorance was dispelled, knowledge arose; darkness was dispelled, light arose, as is fitting for one who abides diligent, ardent, and resolute. This, brahmin, was my second breakthrough, like that of the chick from its eggshell.

‘With the mind thus concentrated, purified, cleansed, unblemished, rid of defilement, pliant, workable, steady, and attained to imperturbability, I directed it to the knowledge of the destruction of the taints. I directly knew as it actually is: “This is suffering”; I directly knew as it actually is: “This is the origin of suffering”; I directly knew as it actually is: “This is the cessation of suffering”; I directly knew as it actually is: “This is the path leading to the cessation of suffering.” I directly knew as it actually is: “These are the taints”; I directly knew as it actually is: “This is the origin of the taints”; I directly knew as it actually is: “This is the cessation of the taints”; I directly knew as it actually is: “This is the path leading to the cessation of the taints.” When I knew and saw thus, my mind was liberated from the taint of sensual desire, my mind was liberated from the taint of existence, and my mind was liberated from the taint of ignorance. With liberation, there arose the knowledge: “Liberated.” I directly knew: “Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what was to be done has been done, there is no more for this state of being.”

‘This, brahmin, was the third knowledge attained by me in the last watch of the night; ignorance was dispelled, knowledge arose; darkness was dispelled, light arose, as is fitting for one who abides diligent, ardent, and resolute. This, brahmin, was my third breakthrough, like that of the chick from its eggshell.’

When this was said, the brahmin Verañja said to the Blessed One: ‘Master Gotama is the eldest, Master Gotama is the foremost! Excellent, Master Gotama, excellent! Just as, Master Gotama, one might set upright what was overturned, or reveal what was hidden, or point out the way to one who was lost, or carry a lamp into the darkness so that those with eyes might see forms – in the same way, the Dhamma has been made clear in various ways by Master Gotama. I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the Dhamma, and to the Saṅgha of bhikkhus. Let Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge from this day forth as long as life lasts.’
sections.sinhala:
මා විසින් මෙසේ අසන ලදි – එක් කලෙක භාග්‍යවතුන් වහන්සේ වේරංජා නුවර නළේරුපූචිමන්ද නම් රුක්මුලෙහි වාසය කරති. ඉක්බිති වේරංජා බ්‍රාහ්මණයා භාග්‍යවතුන් වහන්සේ වැඩසිටි තැනට පැමිණියේය. පැමිණ භාග්‍යවතුන් වහන්සේ සමඟ සතුටු විය. සතුටු විය යුතු සිහි කටයුතු කථා බස් නිමවා එකත්පසෙකින් හිඳගත්තේය. එකත්පසෙකින් හිඳගත් වේරංජා බ්‍රාහ්මණයා භාග්‍යවතුන් වහන්සේට මෙය පැවසුවේය: “භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්ස, මා මේ කාරණය අසා ඇත: ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා වයසට ගිය, මහලු, වියපත්, ජීවිතයේ අවසාන භාගයට පැමිණ සිටින බමුණන්ට ආචාර කරන්නේ හෝ නැගිට හිඳින්නට ආරාධනා කරන්නේ හෝ ආසනයකින් සංග්‍රහ කරන්නේ නැත’ යනුවෙනි. භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්ස, ඒ කාරණය එසේමය. භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේ වයසට ගිය, මහලු, වියපත්, ජීවිතයේ අවසාන භාගයට පැමිණ සිටින බමුණන්ට ආචාර කරන්නේ හෝ නැගිට හිඳින්නට ආරාධනා කරන්නේ හෝ ආසනයකින් සංග්‍රහ කරන්නේ නැත. භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්ස, ඒ කාරණය සුදුසු නොවේ.”

“බ්‍රාහ්මණය, දෙවිවරුන් සහිත මරුන් සහිත බඹුන් සහිත, ශ්‍රමණ බ්‍රාහ්මණ සහිත වූ, දෙවි මිනිසුන් සහිත වූ මේ ලෝකයේ මම එවැනි අයෙක් නොදකිමි, යමෙකුට මා ආචාර කළ යුතු හෝ නැගිට ආසනයක් දිය යුතු හෝ ආසනයකින් සංග්‍රහ කළ යුතු හෝ වේද. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, යමෙකුට තථාගතයාණන් වහන්සේ ආචාර කරන්නේ නම්, හෝ නැගිටින්නේ නම්, හෝ ආසනයකින් සංග්‍රහ කරන්නේ නම්, ඔහුගේ හිස පවා පිපිරී යන්නේය.”

“භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේ රස රහිත කෙනෙකි!”

“බ්‍රාහ්මණය, යම් ආකාරයකින් මා නිවැරදිව ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා රස රහිතය’යි කියන්නේ නම්, එයට ක්‍රමයක් ඇත. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, යම් රූප රසයන්, ශබ්ද රසයන්, ගන්ධ රසයන්, රසයන්, ස්පර්ශ රසයන් වේද, ඒවා තථාගතයාණන් වහන්සේට ප්‍රහීණ කරනු ලැබ, මුල් සිඳ දමනු ලැබ, තල් ගසක් මෙන් හිස් කරනු ලැබ, අභාවයට පත් කරනු ලැබ, අනාගතයේදී නැවත ඇති නොවන ස්වභාවයට පත් කර ඇත. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මා ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා රස රහිතය’යි නිවැරදිව කියන්නේ නම්, එයට ඇති ක්‍රමය මෙයයි. එහෙත් ඔබ අදහස් කරන කාරණය නම් නොවේ.”

“භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේ භෝග රහිත කෙනෙකි!”

“බ්‍රාහ්මණය, යම් ආකාරයකින් මා නිවැරදිව ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා භෝග රහිතය’යි කියන්නේ නම්, එයට ක්‍රමයක් ඇත. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, යම් රූප භෝගයන්, ශබ්ද භෝගයන්, ගන්ධ භෝගයන්, රස භෝගයන්, ස්පර්ශ භෝගයන් වේද, ඒවා තථාගතයාණන් වහන්සේට ප්‍රහීණ කරනු ලැබ, මුල් සිඳ දමනු ලැබ, තල් ගසක් මෙන් හිස් කරනු ලැබ, අභාවයට පත් කරනු ලැබ, අනාගතයේදී නැවත ඇති නොවන ස්වභාවයට පත් කර ඇත. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මා ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා භෝග රහිතය’යි නිවැරදිව කියන්නේ නම්, එයට ඇති ක්‍රමය මෙයයි. එහෙත් ඔබ අදහස් කරන කාරණය නම් නොවේ.”

“භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේ අක්‍රියවාදියෙකි!”

“බ්‍රාහ්මණය, යම් ආකාරයකින් මා නිවැරදිව ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා අක්‍රියවාදියෙකි’යි කියන්නේ නම්, එයට ක්‍රමයක් ඇත. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මම කාය දුෂ්චරිතයේ, වචී දුෂ්චරිතයේ, මනෝ දුෂ්චරිතයේ අක්‍ියාව (නොකර සිටීම) ගැන කියමි. නොයෙක් ආකාර වූ පාපී අකුසල ධර්මයන් නොකිරීම ගැන මම කියමි. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මා ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා අක්‍රියවාදියෙකි’යි නිවැරදිව කියන්නේ නම්, එයට ඇති ක්‍රමය මෙයයි. එහෙත් ඔබ අදහස් කරන කාරණය නම් නොවේ.”

“භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේ උච්ඡේදවාදියෙකි!”

“බ්‍රාහ්මණය, යම් ආකාරයකින් මා නිවැරදිව ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා උච්ඡේදවාදියෙකි’යි කියන්නේ නම්, එයට ක්‍රමයක් ඇත. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මම රාගයේ, ද්වේෂයේ, මෝහයේ උච්ඡේදය (විනාශ කිරීම) ගැන කියමි. නොයෙක් ආකාර වූ පාපී අකුසල ධර්මයන් විනාශ කිරීම ගැන මම කියමි. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මා ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා උච්ඡේදවාදියෙකි’යි නිවැරදිව කියන්නේ නම්, එයට ඇති ක්‍රමය මෙයයි. එහෙත් ඔබ අදහස් කරන කාරණය නම් නොවේ.”

“භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේ පිළිකුල් කරන කෙනෙකි!”

“බ්‍රාහ්මණය, යම් ආකාරයකින් මා නිවැරදිව ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා පිළිකුල් කරන කෙනෙකි’යි කියන්නේ නම්, එයට ක්‍රමයක් ඇත. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මම කාය දුෂ්චරිතයට, වචී දුෂ්චරිතයට, මනෝ දුෂ්චරිතයට පිළිකුල් කරමි. නොයෙක් ආකාර වූ පාපී අකුසල ධර්මයන්ට සමවැදීම (යෙදීම) මම පිළිකුල් කරමි. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මා ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා පිළිකුල් කරන කෙනෙකි’යි නිවැරදිව කියන්නේ නම්, එයට ඇති ක්‍රමය මෙයයි. එහෙත් ඔබ අදහස් කරන කාරණය නම් නොවේ.”

“භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේ විනය කාරක කෙනෙකි!”

“බ්‍රාහ්මණය, යම් ආකාරයකින් මා නිවැරදිව ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා විනය කාරක කෙනෙකි’යි කියන්නේ නම්, එයට ක්‍රමයක් ඇත. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මම රාගය, ද්වේෂය, මෝහය විනය කිරීමට (සංවර කිරීමට, දුරලීමට) ධර්මය දේශනා කරමි. නොයෙක් ආකාර වූ පාපී අකුසල ධර්මයන් දුරලීම පිණිස මම ධර්මය දේශනා කරමි. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මා ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා විනය කාරක කෙනෙකි’යි නිවැරදිව කියන්නේ නම්, එයට ඇති ක්‍රමය මෙයයි. එහෙත් ඔබ අදහස් කරන කාරණය නම් නොවේ.”

“භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේ තපස් රකින කෙනෙකි!”

“බ්‍රාහ්මණය, යම් ආකාරයකින් මා නිවැරදිව ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා තපස් රකින කෙනෙකි’යි කියන්නේ නම්, එයට ක්‍රමයක් ඇත. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මම කාය දුෂ්චරිතය, වචී දුෂ්චරිතය, මනෝ දුෂ්චරිතය යන පාපී අකුසල ධර්මයන් තැවිය යුතු (දුරු කළ යුතු) දේ ලෙස පවසමි. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, යමෙකුට තැවිය යුතු පාපී අකුසල ධර්මයන් ප්‍රහීණ කරනු ලැබ, මුල් සිඳ දමනු ලැබ, තල් ගසක් මෙන් හිස් කරනු ලැබ, අභාවයට පත් කරනු ලැබ, අනාගතයේදී නැවත ඇති නොවන ස්වභාවයට පත් කර ඇත්ද, මම ඔහු ‘තපස් රකින කෙනෙකි’යි කියමි. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, තථාගතයාණන් වහන්සේට තැවිය යුතු පාපී අකුසල ධර්මයන් ප්‍රහීණ කරනු ලැබ, මුල් සිඳ දමනු ලැබ, තල් ගසක් මෙන් හිස් කරනු ලැබ, අභාවයට පත් කරනු ලැබ, අනාගතයේදී නැවත ඇති නොවන ස්වභාවයට පත් කර ඇත. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මා ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා තපස් රකින කෙනෙකි’යි නිවැරදිව කියන්නේ නම්, එයට ඇති ක්‍රමය මෙයයි. එහෙත් ඔබ අදහස් කරන කාරණය නම් නොවේ.”

“භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේ ගැබ් ගැනීමෙන් තොර කෙනෙකි!”

“බ්‍රාහ්මණය, යම් ආකාරයකින් මා නිවැරදිව ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා ගැබ් ගැනීමෙන් තොර කෙනෙකි’යි කියන්නේ නම්, එයට ක්‍රමයක් ඇත. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, යමෙකුට අනාගතයේදී ගැබ්ගැනීම්, නැවත භවයක් ඇතිවීම් ප්‍රහීණ කරනු ලැබ, මුල් සිඳ දමනු ලැබ, තල් ගසක් මෙන් හිස් කරනු ලැබ, අභාවයට පත් කරනු ලැබ, අනාගතයේදී නැවත ඇති නොවන ස්වභාවයට පත් කර ඇත්ද, මම ඔහු ‘ගැබ් ගැනීමෙන් තොර කෙනෙකි’යි කියමි. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, තථාගතයාණන් වහන්සේට අනාගතයේදී ගැබ්ගැනීම්, නැවත භවයක් ඇතිවීම් ප්‍රහීණ කරනු ලැබ, මුල් සිඳ දමනු ලැබ, තල් ගසක් මෙන් හිස් කරනු ලැබ, අභාවයට පත් කරනු ලැබ, අනාගතයේදී නැවත ඇති නොවන ස්වභාවයට පත් කර ඇත. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මා ‘ගෞතම ශ්‍රමණයා ගැබ් ගැනීමෙන් තොර කෙනෙකි’යි නිවැරදිව කියන්නේ නම්, එයට ඇති ක්‍රමය මෙයයි. එහෙත් ඔබ අදහස් කරන කාරණය නම් නොවේ.”

“බ්‍රාහ්මණය, යම්සේ කිකිළියකගේ බිත්තර අටක් හෝ දහයක් හෝ දොළහක් වේද, ඒවා කිකිළිය විසින් මනාව උණුසුම් කරනු ලැබ, මනාව සෙවණ කරනු ලැබ, මනාව පෝෂණය කරනු ලැබ ඇත්තාහ. ඒ කිකිළි පැටවුන් අතුරින් යමෙක් පළමුවෙන් පාදයේ නිය තුඩකින් හෝ හොට තුඩකින් හෝ බිත්තර කවචය බිඳගෙන ආරක්ෂිතව පිටතට එන්නේද, ඔහුට ‘ජ්‍යේෂ්ඨයාද, කනිට්ඨයාද’ කියා කුමක් කිය යුතුද?” “භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්ස, ඔහුට ‘ජ්‍යේෂ්ඨයා’ කියා කිය යුතුය. මක්නිසාද යත්, භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්ස, ඔහු ඔවුන් අතුරින් ජ්‍යේෂ්ඨයා වන බැවිනි.”

“බ්‍රාහ්මණය, එපරිද්දෙන්ම අවිද්‍යාවෙන් පෙළෙන, බිත්තරයක් මෙන් වැසීගත්, අවිද්‍යා කවචයෙන් බැඳී සිටින සත්ව ප්‍රජාවට, අවිද්‍යා බිත්තර කවචය බිඳ දමා, මම එකම තැනැත්තා ලෙස ලෝකයේ අනුත්තර වූ සම්මා සම්බෝධියට පැමිණියෙමි. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මම ලෝකයට ජ්‍යේෂ්ඨයා ද ශ්‍රේෂ්ඨයා ද වෙමි. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මාගේ වීර්යය අලස බවකින් තොරව ආරම්භ කර තිබිණි. සිහිය මුළා නොවී උපස්ථිත විය. කය සන්සුන් විය, නොසන්සුන් නොවීය. සිත එකඟ විය, සමාධිගත විය.

“බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මම කාමයන්ගෙන් වෙන්ව ද අකුසල ධර්මයන්ගෙන් වෙන්ව ද විතර්ක සහිත, විචාර සහිත, විවේකයෙන් හටගත් ප්‍රීති සුඛය සහිත වූ පළමු ධ්‍යානයට පැමිණ වාසය කළෙමි. විතර්ක විචාරයන් සංසිඳීමෙන්, අභ්‍යන්තර පැහැදීමෙන්, චිත්ත ඒකාග්‍රතාවයෙන්, විතර්ක රහිත, විචාර රහිත, සමාධියෙන් හටගත් ප්‍රීති සුඛය සහිත වූ දෙවන ධ්‍යානයට පැමිණ වාසය කළෙමි. ප්‍රීතිය ද වෙන් කිරීමෙන්, උපේක්ෂාවෙන් යුතුව වාසය කරමින්, සිහි ඇතිව, මනා ප්‍රඥාවෙන් යුතුව, කයින් සුඛය අත්විඳිමින්, ආර්යයෝ ‘උපේක්ෂාවෙන් යුක්තව, සිහි ඇතිව, සුඛ විහරණයෙන් යුක්තව වාසය කරයි’යි පවසන, තෙවන ධ්‍යානයට පැමිණ වාසය කළෙමි. සුඛය ද ප්‍රහීණ කිරීමෙන්, දුක්ඛය ද ප්‍රහීණ කිරීමෙන්, පෙර තිබූ සෝමනස්ස දෝමනස්සයන් අතුරුදන් වීමෙන්, දුක් නොවන සුඛ නොවන උපේක්ෂා සිහි පිරිසිදු බව සහිත වූ සිව්වන ධ්‍යානයට පැමිණ වාසය කළෙමි.

“මා එසේ සමාධිගත වූ, පිරිසිදු වූ, පවිත්‍ර වූ, කෙලෙස් රහිත වූ, පහව ගිය උපක්ලේශ ඇති, මෘදු වූ, කර්මයට සුදුසු වූ, ස්ථිර වූ, චලනයෙන් තොර වූ සිත පූර්ව නිවාස අනුස්සති ඥානය සඳහා යොමු කළෙමි. මම නොයෙක් ආකාර වූ පූර්ව නිවාස සිහිපත් කළෙමි. එනම්, එක් ජාතියක් ද, ජාති දෙකක් ද, ජාති තුනක් ද, ජාති හතරක් ද, ජාති පහක් ද, ජාති දහයක් ද, ජාති විස්සක් ද, ජාති තිහක් ද, ජාති හතළිහක් ද, ජාති පනහක් ද, ජාති සියයක් ද, ජාති දහසක් ද, ජාති ලක්ෂයක් ද, නොයෙක් සංවට්ට කල්පයන් ද, නොයෙක් විවට්ට කල්පයන් ද, නොයෙක් සංවට්ට-විවට්ට කල්පයන් ද සිහිපත් කළෙමි. එනම්: ‘මම අසවල් තැන, මේ නම ඇති, මේ ගෝත්‍රය ඇති, මේ වර්ණය ඇති, මේ ආහාර ඇති, මෙසේ සුඛ දුක් අත්විඳිමින්, මේ ආයුෂ අවසන් කළ කෙනෙක් වීමි. මම එතැනින් චුත වී අසවල් තැන උපන්නෙමි. එතැනද මම මේ නම ඇති, මේ ගෝත්‍රය ඇති, මේ වර්ණය ඇති, මේ ආහාර ඇති, මෙසේ සුඛ දුක් අත්විඳිමින්, මේ ආයුෂ අවසන් කළ කෙනෙක් වීමි. මම එතැනින් චුත වී මෙතැන උපන්නෙමි’ කියාය. මෙසේ ස්වභාවයන් සහිතව, අරමුණු සහිතව, නොයෙක් ආකාර වූ පූර්ව නිවාස මම සිහිපත් කළෙමි. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, රාත්‍රියේ පළමු යාමයේදී මා විසින් මේ පළමු විද්‍යාව අවබෝධ කරගන්නා ලදි. අවිද්‍යාව පහ කරන ලදි. විද්‍යාව පහළ විය. අන්ධකාරය දුරු කරන ලදි. ආලෝකය පහළ විය. යම්සේ අප්‍රමාදීව, වීර්යවත්ව, ස්වකීය සිත යොදවා වාසය කරන කෙනෙකුට එය සිදු වේද එසේය. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, කිකිළි පැටවෙකුට බිත්තර කවචයෙන් පිටතට ඒම මෙන්, මාගේ මේ පළමු අවබෝධය විය.

“මා එසේ සමාධිගත වූ, පිරිසිදු වූ, පවිත්‍ර වූ, කෙලෙස් රහිත වූ, පහව ගිය උපක්ලේශ ඇති, මෘදු වූ, කර්මයට සුදුසු වූ, ස්ථිර වූ, චලනයෙන් තොර වූ සිත සත්වයන්ගේ චුති-උපත් ඥානය සඳහා යොමු කළෙමි. මම පිරිසිදු, මනුෂ්‍ය ඇස ඉක්මවා ගිය දිව්‍ය චක්ෂුසින්, සත්වයන් චුත වන අයුරු ද උපදින අයුරු ද, හීන වූ අය ද ප්‍රණීත වූ අය ද, සුන්දර වූ අය ද අවලක්ෂණ වූ අය ද, සුගතිගාමී වූ අය ද දුර්ගතිගාමී වූ අය ද දකිමි. කර්මානුරූපව ගමන් කරන සත්වයන් මෙසේ හඳුනාගනිමි: ‘මේ භවත් සත්වයෝ කාය දුෂ්චරිතයෙන් යුක්තව, වචී දුෂ්චරිතයෙන් යුක්තව, මනෝ දුෂ්චරිතයෙන් යුක්තව, ආර්යයන්ට අපහාස කරන්නන් ලෙස, මිථ්‍යා දෘෂ්ටිකයන් ලෙස, මිථ්‍යා දෘෂ්ටික කර්ම සමාදන් වූවන් ලෙස සිටියහ. ඔවුන් කය බිඳී මරණින් පසු අපාය නම් දුර්ගතියට, විනිපාත නම් නිරයට උපන්නාහ. මේ භවත් සත්වයෝ කාය සුචරිතයෙන් යුක්තව, වචී සුචරිතයෙන් යුක්තව, මනෝ සුචරිතයෙන් යුක්තව, ආර්යයන්ට අපහාස නොකරන්නන් ලෙස, සම්මා දෘෂ්ටිකයන් ලෙස, සම්මා දෘෂ්ටික කර්ම සමාදන් වූවන් ලෙස සිටියහ. ඔවුන් කය බිඳී මරණින් පසු සුගතියට, ස්වර්ග ලෝකයට උපන්නාහ’ කියාය. මෙසේ පිරිසිදු, මනුෂ්‍ය ඇස ඉක්මවා ගිය දිව්‍ය චක්ෂුසින්, සත්වයන් චුත වන අයුරු ද උපදින අයුරු ද, හීන වූ අය ද ප්‍රණීත වූ අය ද, සුන්දර වූ අය ද අවලක්ෂණ වූ අය ද, සුගතිගාමී වූ අය ද දුර්ගතිගාමී වූ අය ද දකිමි. කර්මානුරූපව ගමන් කරන සත්වයන් හඳුනාගනිමි. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, රාත්‍රියේ මැද යාමයේදී මා විසින් මේ දෙවන විද්‍යාව අවබෝධ කරගන්නා ලදි. අවිද්‍යාව පහ කරන ලදි. විද්‍යාව පහළ විය. අන්ධකාරය දුරු කරන ලදි. ආලෝකය පහළ විය. යම්සේ අප්‍රමාදීව, වීර්යවත්ව, ස්වකීය සිත යොදවා වාසය කරන කෙනෙකුට එය සිදු වේද එසේය. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, කිකිළි පැටවෙකුට බිත්තර කවචයෙන් පිටතට ඒම මෙන්, මාගේ මේ දෙවන අවබෝධය විය.

“මා එසේ සමාධිගත වූ, පිරිසිදු වූ, පවිත්‍ර වූ, කෙලෙස් රහිත වූ, පහව ගිය උපක්ලේශ ඇති, මෘදු වූ, කර්මයට සුදුසු වූ, ස්ථිර වූ, චලනයෙන් තොර වූ සිත ආශ්‍රව ක්ෂය ඥානය සඳහා යොමු කළෙමි. මම ‘මෙය දුකයි’ කියා යථාභූත ඥානයෙන් අවබෝධ කළෙමි. ‘මෙය දුක හටගැනීමයි’ කියා යථාභූත ඥානයෙන් අවබෝධ කළෙමි. ‘මෙය දුක නැතිකිරීමයි’ කියා යථාභූත ඥානයෙන් අවබෝධ කළෙමි. ‘මෙය දුක නැති කිරීමට යන මාර්ගයයි’ කියා යථාභූත ඥානයෙන් අවබෝධ කළෙමි. ‘මේවා ආශ්‍රවයෝ’ කියා යථාභූත ඥානයෙන් අවබෝධ කළෙමි. ‘මෙය ආශ්‍රවයන් හටගැනීමයි’ කියා යථාභූත ඥානයෙන් අවබෝධ කළෙමි. ‘මෙය ආශ්‍රවයන් නැතිකිරීමයි’ කියා යථාභූත ඥානයෙන් අවබෝධ කළෙමි. ‘මෙය ආශ්‍රවයන් නැති කිරීමට යන මාර්ගයයි’ කියා යථාභූත ඥානයෙන් අවබෝධ කළෙමි. මා මෙසේ දන්නා, මෙසේ දකින කල්හි කාමාශ්‍රවයෙන් ද සිත මිදුණේය. භවාශ්‍රවයෙන් ද සිත මිදුණේය. අවිද්‍යාශ්‍රවයෙන් ද සිත මිදුණේය. මිදුණ කල්හි, ‘මිදුණා’ යන ඥානය ඇති විය. ‘ජාතිය ක්ෂය විය, බ්‍රහ්මචර්යාව වාසය කරන ලදි, කළ යුතු දේ කරන ලදි, මේ තත්ත්වයෙන් (අර්හත් බවෙන්) පසුව තවත් භවයක් නැත’ කියා අවබෝධ කළෙමි. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, රාත්‍රියේ අවසාන යාමයේදී මා විසින් මේ තෙවන විද්‍යාව අවබෝධ කරගන්නා ලදි. අවිද්‍යාව පහ කරන ලදි. විද්‍යාව පහළ විය. අන්ධකාරය දුරු කරන ලදි. ආලෝකය පහළ විය. යම්සේ අප්‍රමාදීව, වීර්යවත්ව, ස්වකීය සිත යොදවා වාසය කරන කෙනෙකුට එය සිදු වේද එසේය. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, කිකිළි පැටවෙකුට බිත්තර කවචයෙන් පිටතට ඒම මෙන්, මාගේ මේ තෙවන අවබෝධය විය.”

මෙසේ පැවසූ කල්හි වේරංජා බ්‍රාහ්මණයා භාග්‍යවතුන් වහන්සේට මෙය පැවසුවේය: “භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේ ජ්‍යේෂ්ඨයෙකි, භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේ ශ්‍රේෂ්ඨයෙකි. භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්ස, ඉතා මනහරයි, ඉතා මනහරයි! භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්ස, යම්සේ යටිකුරු කළ දෙයක් උඩුකුරු කරන්නේද, වසා තැබූ දෙයක් විවෘත කරන්නේද, මඟ මුළා වූවෙකුට මඟ පෙන්වන්නේද, අන්ධකාරයේ තෙල් පහනක් දල්වන්නේද – ඇස් ඇත්තෝ රූප දකින්නාක් මෙන්, එසේම භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේ විසින් නොයෙක් ආකාරයෙන් ධර්මය ප්‍රකාශ කරන ලදි. මම භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේ ද, ධර්මය ද, භික්ෂු සංඝයා ද සරණ යමි. භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේ අද පටන් දිවි හිමියෙන් සරණ ගිය උපාසකයෙකු ලෙස මා පිළිගන්නා සේක්වා!”

sections.pali: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ. Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā abhiññātā abhiññātā licchavī santhāgāre [sandhāgāre (ka.)] sannisinnā sannipatitā anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti, dhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti, saṅghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti. Tena kho pana samayena sīho senāpati nigaṇṭhasāvako tassaṃ parisāyaṃ nisinno hoti. Atha kho sīhassa senāpatissa etadahosi – ‘‘nissaṃsayaṃ kho so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bhavissati, tathā hime sambahulā abhiññātā abhiññātā licchavī santhāgāre sannisinnā sannipatitā anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti, dhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti, saṅghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti. Yaṃnūnāhaṃ taṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkameyyaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddha’’nti. Atha kho sīho senāpati yena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto [nāthaputto (ka. sī.), nātaputto (ka. sī.)] tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘icchāmahaṃ, bhante, samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitu’’nti. ‘‘Kiṃ pana tvaṃ, sīha, kiriyavādo samāno akiriyavādaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissasi? Samaṇo hi, sīha, gotamo akiriyavādo, akiriyāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’ti. Atha kho sīhassa senāpatissa yo ahosi gamiyābhisaṅkhāro [gamikābhisaṅkhāro (ka. sī.) mahāva. 290] bhagavantaṃ dassanāya, so paṭippassambhi. Dutiyampi kho sambahulā abhiññātā abhiññātā licchavī santhāgāre sannisinnā sannipatitā anekapariyāyena buddhassa…pe… dhammassa…pe… saṅghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti. Dutiyampi kho sīhassa senāpatissa etadahosi – ‘‘nissaṃsayaṃ kho so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bhavissati, tathā hime sambahulā abhiññātā abhiññātā licchavī santhāgāre sannisinnā sannipatitā anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti, dhammassa…pe… saṅghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti. Yaṃnūnāhaṃ taṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkameyyaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddha’’nti. Atha kho sīho senāpati yena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘icchāmahaṃ, bhante, samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitu’’nti. ‘‘Kiṃ pana tvaṃ, sīha, kiriyavādo samāno akiriyavādaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissasi? Samaṇo hi, sīha, gotamo akiriyavādo akiriyāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’ti. Dutiyampi kho sīhassa senāpatissa yo ahosi gamiyābhisaṅkhāro bhagavantaṃ dassanāya, so paṭippassambhi. Tatiyampi kho sambahulā abhiññātā abhiññātā licchavī santhāgāre sannisinnā sannipatitā anekapariyāyena buddhassa…pe… dhammassa…pe… saṅghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti. Tatiyampi kho sīhassa senāpatissa etadahosi – ‘‘nissaṃsayaṃ kho so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bhavissati, tathā hime sambahulā abhiññātā abhiññātā licchavī santhāgāre sannisinnā sannipatitā anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti, dhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti, saṅghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti. Kiṃ hime karissanti nigaṇṭhā apalokitā vā anapalokitā vā? Yaṃnūnāhaṃ anapaloketvāva nigaṇṭhe [nigaṇṭhaṃ (syā. ka.) mahāva. 290 passitabbaṃ] taṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkameyyaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddha’’nti. Atha kho sīho senāpati pañcamattehi rathasatehi divādivassa vesāliyā niyyāsi bhagavantaṃ dassanāya. Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi, yānena gantvā yānā paccorohitvā pattikova agamāsi. Atha kho sīho senāpati yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho sīho senāpati bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘Sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante – ‘akiriyavādo samaṇo gotamo, akiriyāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’ti. Ye te, bhante, evamāhaṃsu – ‘akiriyavādo samaṇo gotamo, akiriyāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’ti, kacci te, bhante, bhagavato vuttavādino na ca bhagavantaṃ abhūtena abbhācikkhanti dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākaronti na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo [vādānupāto (ka. sī. syā.) a. ni. 3.58; 5.5] gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgacchati? Anabbhakkhātukāmā hi mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavanta’’nti. ‘‘Atthi, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘akiriyavādo samaṇo gotamo, akiriyāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’’ti. ‘‘Atthi, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘kiriyavādo samaṇo gotamo, kiriyāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’’ti. ‘‘Atthi, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘ucchedavādo samaṇo gotamo, ucchedāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’’ti. ‘‘Atthi, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘jegucchī samaṇo gotamo, jegucchitāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’’ti. ‘‘Atthi, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘venayiko samaṇo gotamo, vinayāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’’ti. ‘‘Atthi, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘tapassī samaṇo gotamo, tapassitāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’’ti. ‘‘Atthi, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘apagabbho samaṇo gotamo, apagabbhatāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’’ti. ‘‘Atthi, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘assāsako samaṇo gotamo, assāsāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’’ti. ‘‘Katamo ca, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘akiriyavādo samaṇo gotamo, akiriyāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’ti? Ahañhi, sīha, akiriyaṃ vadāmi kāyaduccaritassa vacīduccaritassa manoduccaritassa; anekavihitānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ akiriyaṃ vadāmi. Ayaṃ kho, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘akiriyavādo samaṇo gotamo, akiriyāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’’ti. ‘‘Katamo ca, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘kiriyavādo samaṇo gotamo, kiriyāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’ti? Ahañhi, sīha, kiriyaṃ vadāmi kāyasucaritassa vacīsucaritassa manosucaritassa; anekavihitānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ kiriyaṃ vadāmi. Ayaṃ kho, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘kiriyavādo samaṇo gotamo, kiriyāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’’ti. ‘‘Katamo ca, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘ucchedavādo samaṇo gotamo, ucchedāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’ti? Ahañhi, sīha, ucchedaṃ vadāmi rāgassa dosassa mohassa; anekavihitānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ucchedaṃ vadāmi. Ayaṃ kho, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘ucchedavādo samaṇo gotamo, ucchedāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’’ti. ‘‘Katamo ca, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘jegucchī samaṇo gotamo, jegucchitāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’ti? Ahañhi, sīha, jigucchāmi kāyaduccaritena vacīduccaritena manoduccaritena; jigucchāmi anekavihitānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ samāpattiyā. Ayaṃ kho, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘jegucchī samaṇo gotamo, jegucchitāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’’ti. ‘‘Katamo ca, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘venayiko samaṇo gotamo, vinayāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’ti? Ahañhi, sīha, vinayāya dhammaṃ desemi rāgassa dosassa mohassa; anekavihitānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ vinayāya dhammaṃ desemi. Ayaṃ kho, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘venayiko samaṇo gotamo, vinayāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’’ti. ‘‘Katamo ca, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘tapassī samaṇo gotamo, tapassitāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’ti? Tapanīyāhaṃ, sīha, pāpake akusale dhamme vadāmi kāyaduccaritaṃ vacīduccaritaṃ manoduccaritaṃ. Yassa kho, sīha, tapanīyā pāpakā akusalā dhammā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṃkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā, tamahaṃ ‘tapassī’ti vadāmi. Tathāgatassa kho, sīha, tapanīyā pāpakā akusalā dhammā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṃkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā. Ayaṃ kho, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘tapassī samaṇo gotamo, tapassitāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’’ti. ‘‘Katamo ca, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘apagabbho samaṇo gotamo, apagabbhatāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’ti? Yassa kho, sīha, āyatiṃ gabbhaseyyā punabbhavābhinibbatti pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṃkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā, tamahaṃ ‘apagabbho’ti vadāmi. Tathāgatassa kho, sīha, āyatiṃ gabbhaseyyā punabbhavābhinibbatti pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṃkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā. Ayaṃ kho, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘apagabbho samaṇo gotamo, apagabbhatāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’’ti. ‘‘Katamo ca, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘assāsako samaṇo gotamo, assāsāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’ti? Ahañhi, sīha, assāsako paramena assāsena, assāsāya dhammaṃ desemi, tena ca sāvake vinemi. Ayaṃ kho, sīha, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya – ‘assāsako samaṇo gotamo, assāsāya dhammaṃ deseti, tena ca sāvake vinetī’’’ti. Evaṃ vutte sīho senāpati bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘abhikkantaṃ, bhante, abhikkantaṃ, bhante… pe… upāsakaṃ maṃ, bhante, bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gata’’nti. ‘‘Anuviccakāraṃ kho, sīha, karohi. Anuviccakāro tumhādisānaṃ ñātamanussānaṃ sādhu hotī’’ti. ‘‘Imināpāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato bhiyyosomattāya attamano abhiraddho, yaṃ maṃ bhagavā evamāha – ‘anuviccakāraṃ kho, sīha, karohi. Anuviccakāro tumhādisānaṃ ñātamanussānaṃ sādhu hotī’ti. Mañhi, bhante, aññatitthiyā sāvakaṃ labhitvā kevalakappaṃ vesāliṃ paṭākaṃ parihareyyuṃ – ‘sīho amhākaṃ senāpati sāvakattaṃ upagato’ti. Atha ca pana bhagavā evamāha – ‘anuviccakāraṃ, sīha, karohi. Anuviccakāro tumhādisānaṃ ñātamanussānaṃ sādhu hotī’ti. Esāhaṃ, bhante, dutiyampi bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca. Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gata’’nti. ‘‘Dīgharattaṃ kho te, sīha, nigaṇṭhānaṃ opānabhūtaṃ kulaṃ, yena nesaṃ upagatānaṃ piṇḍakaṃ dātabbaṃ maññeyyāsī’’ti. ‘‘Imināpāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato bhiyyosomattāya attamano abhiraddho, yaṃ maṃ bhagavā evamāha – ‘dīgharattaṃ kho te, sīha, nigaṇṭhānaṃ opānabhūtaṃ kulaṃ, yena nesaṃ upagatānaṃ piṇḍakaṃ dātabbaṃ maññeyyāsī’ti. Sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante – ‘samaṇo gotamo evamāha – mayhameva dānaṃ dātabbaṃ, mayhameva sāvakānaṃ dātabbaṃ; mayhameva dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ, na aññesaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ; mayhameva sāvakānaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ, na aññesaṃ sāvakānaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphala’nti, atha ca pana maṃ bhagavā nigaṇṭhesupi dāne samādapeti [samādāpeti (?)]. Api ca, bhante, mayamettha kālaṃ jānissāma. Esāhaṃ, bhante, tatiyampi bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca. Upāsakaṃ maṃ, bhante, bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gata’’nti. Atha kho bhagavā sīhassa senāpatissa anupubbiṃ kathaṃ [anupubbikathaṃ (sabbattha)] kathesi, seyyathidaṃ – dānakathaṃ sīlakathaṃ saggakathaṃ, kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṃkilesaṃ nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi. Yadā bhagavā aññāsi sīhaṃ senāpatiṃ kallacittaṃ muducittaṃ vinīvaraṇacittaṃ udaggacittaṃ pasannacittaṃ, atha yā buddhānaṃ sāmukkaṃsikā dhammadesanā taṃ pakāsesi – dukkhaṃ samudayaṃ nirodhaṃ maggaṃ. Seyyathāpi nāma suddhaṃ vatthaṃ apagatakāḷakaṃ sammadeva rajanaṃ paṭiggaṇheyya; evamevaṃ sīhassa senāpatissa tasmiṃyeva āsane virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi – ‘‘yaṃ kiñci samudayadhammaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ nirodhadhamma’’nti. Atha kho sīho senāpati diṭṭhadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogāḷhadhammo tiṇṇavicikiccho vigatakathaṃkatho vesārajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusāsane bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘adhivāsetu me, bhante, bhagavā svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā’’ti. Adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvena. Atha kho sīho senāpati bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi. Atha kho sīho senāpati aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi – ‘‘gaccha tvaṃ, ambho purisa, pavattamaṃsaṃ jānāhī’’ti. Atha kho sīho senāpati tassā rattiyā accayena sake nivesane paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā bhagavato kālaṃ ārocāpesi – ‘‘kālo, bhante! Niṭṭhitaṃ bhatta’’nti. Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena sīhassa senāpatissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena. Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā nigaṇṭhā vesāliyaṃ rathikāya rathikaṃ [rathiyāya rathiyaṃ (bahūsu)] siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṃ bāhā paggayha kandanti – ‘‘ajja sīhena senāpatinā thūlaṃ pasuṃ vadhitvā samaṇassa gotamassa bhattaṃ kataṃ. Taṃ samaṇo gotamo jānaṃ uddissakataṃ maṃsaṃ paribhuñjati paṭiccakamma’’nti. Atha kho aññataro puriso yena sīho senāpati tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā sīhassa senāpatissa upakaṇṇake ārocesi – ‘‘yagghe, bhante, jāneyyāsi! Ete sambahulā nigaṇṭhā vesāliyaṃ rathikāya rathikaṃ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṃ bāhā paggayha kandanti – ‘ajja sīhena senāpatinā thūlaṃ pasuṃ vadhitvā samaṇassa gotamassa bhattaṃ kataṃ. Taṃ samaṇo gotamo jānaṃ uddissakataṃ maṃsaṃ paribhuñjati paṭiccakamma’nti. Alaṃ ayyo dīgharattañhi te āyasmanto avaṇṇakāmā buddhassa avaṇṇakāmā dhammassa avaṇṇakāmā saṅghassa. Na ca panete āyasmanto jiridanti taṃ bhagavantaṃ asatā tucchā musā abhūtena abbhācikkhituṃ; na ca mayaṃ jīvitahetupi sañcicca pāṇaṃ jīvitā voropeyyāmā’’ti. Atha kho sīho senāpati buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi. Atha kho sīho senāpati bhagavantaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho sīhaṃ senāpatiṃ bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmīti. Dutiyaṃ.

At one time, the Blessed One was staying in Vesālī, in the Gabled Hall of the Great Wood. Now at that time, many well-known and distinguished Licchavis were sitting together, gathered in the assembly hall, speaking in many ways in praise of the Buddha, in praise of the Dhamma, and in praise of the Saṅgha. At that time, General Sīha, a follower of the Nigaṇṭhas, was sitting in that assembly. Then it occurred to General Sīha: "Surely, that Blessed One must be an Arahant, a Fully Self-Enlightened One, since these many well-known and distinguished Licchavis are sitting together, gathered in the assembly hall, speaking in many ways in praise of the Buddha, in praise of the Dhamma, and in praise of the Saṅgha. What if I were to go to see that Blessed One, the Arahant, the Fully Self-Enlightened One?" Then General Sīha approached Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta, and having approached him, he said to Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta: "Venerable sir, I wish to go to see the ascetic Gotama." "But Sīha, being one who teaches action, why do you wish to go to see the ascetic Gotama, who teaches non-action? Indeed, Sīha, the ascetic Gotama is a teacher of non-action; he teaches non-action, and by that he trains his disciples." Then the impulse that General Sīha had to go see the Blessed One subsided. A second time, many well-known and distinguished Licchavis were sitting together, gathered in the assembly hall, speaking in many ways in praise of the Buddha, in praise of the Dhamma, and in praise of the Saṅgha. A second time, it occurred to General Sīha: "Surely, that Blessed One must be an Arahant, a Fully Self-Enlightened One, since these many well-known and distinguished Licchavis are sitting together, gathered in the assembly hall, speaking in many ways in praise of the Buddha, in praise of the Dhamma, and in praise of the Saṅgha. What if I were to go to see that Blessed One, the Arahant, the Fully Self-Enlightened One?" Then General Sīha approached Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta, and having approached him, he said to Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta: "Venerable sir, I wish to go to see the ascetic Gotama." "But Sīha, being one who teaches action, why do you wish to go to see the ascetic Gotama, who teaches non-action? Indeed, Sīha, the ascetic Gotama is a teacher of non-action; he teaches non-action, and by that he trains his disciples." A second time, the impulse that General Sīha had to go see the Blessed One subsided. A third time, many well-known and distinguished Licchavis were sitting together, gathered in the assembly hall, speaking in many ways in praise of the Buddha, in praise of the Dhamma, and in praise of the Saṅgha. A third time, it occurred to General Sīha: "Surely, that Blessed One must be an Arahant, a Fully Self-Enlightened One, since these many well-known and distinguished Licchavis are sitting together, gathered in the assembly hall, speaking in many ways in praise of the Buddha, in praise of the Dhamma, and in praise of the Saṅgha. What will these Nigaṇṭhas do to me, whether I consult them or not? What if I were to go to see that Blessed One, the Arahant, the Fully Self-Enlightened One, without consulting the Nigaṇṭhas?" Then General Sīha, with about five hundred chariots, set out from Vesālī in broad daylight to see the Blessed One. He went by vehicle as far as the ground was passable for vehicles, then he dismounted from his vehicle and proceeded on foot. Then General Sīha approached the Blessed One, and having approached and paid homage to the Blessed One, he sat down to one side.

Seated to one side, General Sīha said to the Blessed One: "Venerable sir, I have heard it said: 'The ascetic Gotama is a teacher of non-action; he teaches non-action, and by that he trains his disciples.' Venerable sir, are those who say this – 'The ascetic Gotama is a teacher of non-action; he teaches non-action, and by that he trains his disciples' – speaking in accordance with what the Blessed One has said, and are they not misrepresenting the Blessed One with what is untrue, and do they explain the Dhamma in accordance with the Dhamma, and is there no co-dharmic dispute or argument that would lead to censure? For we do not wish to misrepresent the Blessed One."

"There is a way, Sīha, in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is a teacher of non-action; he teaches non-action, and by that he trains his disciples.' There is a way, Sīha, in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is a teacher of action; he teaches action, and by that he trains his disciples.' There is a way, Sīha, in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is an annihilationist; he teaches annihilation, and by that he trains his disciples.' There is a way, Sīha, in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is one who detests; he teaches detestation, and by that he trains his disciples.' There is a way, Sīha, in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is a disciplinarian; he teaches discipline, and by that he trains his disciples.' There is a way, Sīha, in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is an ascetic; he teaches ascetic practice, and by that he trains his disciples.' There is a way, Sīha, in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is one who is free from rebirth; he teaches freedom from rebirth, and by that he trains his disciples.' There is a way, Sīha, in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is one who brings comfort; he teaches comfort, and by that he trains his disciples.'"

"And what is the way, Sīha, in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is a teacher of non-action; he teaches non-action, and by that he trains his disciples'? Indeed, Sīha, I teach non-doing of bad bodily conduct, bad verbal conduct, and bad mental conduct. I teach non-doing of various evil, unwholesome states. This, Sīha, is the way in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is a teacher of non-action; he teaches non-action, and by that he trains his disciples.'"

"And what is the way, Sīha, in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is a teacher of action; he teaches action, and by that he trains his disciples'? Indeed, Sīha, I teach doing of good bodily conduct, good verbal conduct, and good mental conduct. I teach doing of various wholesome states. This, Sīha, is the way in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is a teacher of action; he teaches action, and by that he trains his disciples.'"

"And what is the way, Sīha, in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is an annihilationist; he teaches annihilation, and by that he trains his disciples'? Indeed, Sīha, I teach the annihilation of lust, hatred, and delusion. I teach the annihilation of various evil, unwholesome states. This, Sīha, is the way in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is an annihilationist; he teaches annihilation, and by that he trains his disciples.'"

"And what is the way, Sīha, in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is one who detests; he teaches detestation, and by that he trains his disciples'? Indeed, Sīha, I detest bad bodily conduct, bad verbal conduct, and bad mental conduct. I detest the accumulation of various evil, unwholesome states. This, Sīha, is the way in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is one who detests; he teaches detestation, and by that he trains his disciples.'"

"And what is the way, Sīha, in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is a disciplinarian; he teaches discipline, and by that he trains his disciples'? Indeed, Sīha, I teach the discipline of lust, hatred, and delusion. I teach the discipline of various evil, unwholesome states. This, Sīha, is the way in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is a disciplinarian; he teaches discipline, and by that he trains his disciples.'"

"And what is the way, Sīha, in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is an ascetic; he teaches ascetic practice, and by that he trains his disciples'? Indeed, Sīha, I describe evil, unwholesome states as things to be burnt away – bad bodily conduct, bad verbal conduct, bad mental conduct. And for whomever, Sīha, these evil, unwholesome states to be burnt away have been abandoned, uprooted, made like a palm-stump, annihilated, and are no longer subject to future arising – him I call 'an ascetic'. For the Tathāgata, Sīha, these evil, unwholesome states to be burnt away have been abandoned, uprooted, made like a palm-stump, annihilated, and are no longer subject to future arising. This, Sīha, is the way in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is an ascetic; he teaches ascetic practice, and by that he trains his disciples.'"

"And what is the way, Sīha, in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is one who is free from rebirth; he teaches freedom from rebirth, and by that he trains his disciples'? And for whomever, Sīha, future conception in a womb and rebirth have been abandoned, uprooted, made like a palm-stump, annihilated, and are no longer subject to future arising – him I call 'one who is free from rebirth'. For the Tathāgata, Sīha, future conception in a womb and rebirth have been abandoned, uprooted, made like a palm-stump, annihilated, and are no longer subject to future arising. This, Sīha, is the way in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is one who is free from rebirth; he teaches freedom from rebirth, and by that he trains his disciples.'"

"And what is the way, Sīha, in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is one who brings comfort; he teaches comfort, and by that he trains his disciples'? Indeed, Sīha, I am one who brings comfort with the highest comfort. I teach comfort, and by that I train my disciples. This, Sīha, is the way in which one would be speaking rightly when saying of me: 'The ascetic Gotama is one who brings comfort; he teaches comfort, and by that he trains his disciples.'"

When this was said, General Sīha said to the Blessed One: "Magnificent, Venerable sir! Magnificent, Venerable sir! Just as if one were to set upright what was overturned, or to reveal what was hidden, or to show the way to one who was lost, or to carry a lamp into the darkness so that those with eyes could see forms—in the same way has the Dhamma been made clear in many ways by the Blessed One. I go for refuge to the Blessed One, to the Dhamma, and to the Saṅgha. May the Blessed One accept me as a lay follower who has taken refuge from this day forth as long as life lasts."

"Consider carefully, Sīha. Careful consideration is good for well-known people like yourself."

"Venerable sir, by this I am even more pleased and satisfied with the Blessed One, that the Blessed One tells me: 'Consider carefully, Sīha. Careful consideration is good for well-known people like yourself.' For if other sects, Venerable sir, had gained me as a disciple, they would carry a banner throughout all of Vesālī, proclaiming: 'General Sīha has become our disciple!' Yet the Blessed One tells me: 'Consider carefully, Sīha. Careful consideration is good for well-known people like yourself.' A second time, Venerable sir, I go for refuge to the Blessed One, to the Dhamma, and to the Saṅgha. May the Blessed One accept me as a lay follower who has taken refuge from this day forth as long as life lasts."

"For a long time, Sīha, your family has been a source of support for the Nigaṇṭhas. You should consider giving them alms when they come."

"Venerable sir, by this I am even more pleased and satisfied with the Blessed One, that the Blessed One tells me: 'For a long time, Sīha, your family has been a source of support for the Nigaṇṭhas. You should consider giving them alms when they come.' Venerable sir, I have heard it said: 'The ascetic Gotama says this: "Alms should be given only to me, alms should be given only to my disciples; that which is given to me is of great fruit, that which is given to others is not of great fruit; that which is given to my disciples is of great fruit, that which is given to the disciples of others is not of great fruit."' Yet the Blessed One exhorts me to give alms even to the Nigaṇṭhas! Nevertheless, Venerable sir, we will know the proper time for this. A third time, Venerable sir, I go for refuge to the Blessed One, to the Dhamma, and to the Saṅgha. May the Blessed One accept me as a lay follower who has taken refuge from this day forth as long as life lasts."

Then the Blessed One gave General Sīha a graduated discourse, that is to say, a discourse on giving, a discourse on morality, a discourse on heaven; he explained the danger, the degradation, and the defilement of sensual pleasures, and the advantages of renunciation. When the Blessed One perceived that General Sīha's mind was prepared, receptive, unhindered, uplifted, and confident, he then expounded the special teaching of the Buddhas: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path. Just as a clean cloth, free from stains, would perfectly absorb dye, so too, right there on that very seat, General Sīha's Dhamma-eye arose, pure and stainless, realizing: "Whatever is subject to arising is subject to cessation."

Then General Sīha, having seen the Dhamma, attained the Dhamma, understood the Dhamma, penetrated the Dhamma, having overcome doubt, having dispelled perplexity, having gained perfect confidence, and having become independent of others in the Teacher's Dispensation, said to the Blessed One: "Venerable sir, may the Blessed One accept a meal from me tomorrow, together with the community of bhikkhus." The Blessed One accepted by remaining silent. Then General Sīha, understanding the Blessed One's acceptance, rose from his seat, paid homage to the Blessed One, circumambulated him clockwise, and departed.

Then General Sīha addressed a certain man: "Go, good man, and find out about fresh meat." Then, after that night, General Sīha had exquisite hard and soft food prepared in his own residence and announced the time to the Blessed One: "It is time, Venerable sir! The meal is ready." Then the Blessed One, having dressed in the morning, took his bowl and robe and went to General Sīha's residence, and having arrived, he sat down on the prepared seat together with the community of bhikkhus.

Now at that time, many Nigaṇṭhas were crying out in Vesālī, going from street to street and from crossroads to crossroads, with arms upraised: "Today, General Sīha has killed a large animal and prepared a meal for the ascetic Gotama. The ascetic Gotama knowingly eats meat specifically prepared for him, meat obtained through another's action." Then a certain man approached General Sīha, and having approached, he whispered in General Sīha's ear: "Please, Venerable sir, be aware! These many Nigaṇṭhas are crying out in Vesālī, going from street to street and from crossroads to crossroads, with arms upraised: 'Today, General Sīha has killed a large animal and prepared a meal for the ascetic Gotama. The ascetic Gotama knowingly eats meat specifically prepared for him, meat obtained through another's action.' Enough, good sir. For a long time, these venerable ones have been eager to malign the Buddha, to malign the Dhamma, and to malign the Saṅgha. Indeed, these venerable ones are not shy about disparaging the Blessed One with what is false, empty, vain, and untrue. We ourselves would not intentionally deprive any living being of life, even for the sake of our own lives."

Then General Sīha, with his own hands, satisfied and amply fed the community of bhikkhus headed by the Buddha with exquisite hard and soft food. When the Blessed One had finished eating and had withdrawn his hand from the bowl, General Sīha sat down to one side. The Blessed One then, with a Dhamma talk, instructed, encouraged, inspired, and delighted General Sīha, who was sitting to one side. Then he rose from his seat and departed.
